The Pros and Cons of Expressways

Furthermore, insofar as savings exist they may be taken by many
persons in some form other than cash. People may take advantage of an
expressway to move further out of town so as to secure more space. For
such individuals total travel costs may not diminish even though cost per
mile has been reduced. To the extent that expressways result in thinning
out the metropolitan area, the owner of a truck fleet serving the area
may also find that at least some of his potential savings have been eaten
up by the need to cover greater distances.

The savings quoted above do provide ammunition for those who
believe that expressways should be financed by taxes assessed specifically
against automobile users—gas taxes, tire taxes, etc. They also justify the
construction of expressways in terms of the net effect on the total resources
of our economy. They can be used to demonstrate that the necessary
expenditure of manpower, capital, and materials is warranted.

All of this, however, presupposes a rational approach to public and
private automobile expenditures which does not, in fact, exist. We spend
money on automobiles and on facilities to serve automobiles to achieve a
wide variety of satisfactions, some of which are measurable in dollars and
cents, but some of which could not be supported on any economic basis.

Potential operating savings are an important factor in the overall
picture, but they should be kept in perspective. We should ask ourselves
first, what is the minimum level of highway service which we wish to
achieve and, second, what is the best method of achieving this goal taking
all factors into account—initial cost, operating cost, number of properties
to be razed, number of families to be displaced, effect on taxes, effect
on the economic base of the City, effect on the central business district,

29

etc. Operating savings represent simply one element in a complex
evaluation process.

Expressway Systems in Large Cities

This Chapter so far has dealt with the characteristics of a single
expressway. No large city can, however, rely on one expressway to handle
its traffic problem, and the relationship of an expressway to other possible
expressways and to the entire pattern of arterial highways within the
city is a matter of importance.

The most authoritative document on the design of expressways is the
publication of the American Association of State Highway Officials en-
titled A Policy on Arterial Highways in Urban Areas. (The recommended
design standards set forth therein serve as the basis for minimum Federal
requirements for the Interstate Highway System.) This document dis-
cusses the type of highway system needed for a large city in these terms:
“ ... the basic pattern of arterial highways is in the form of a wheel.
Radial routes are the spokes; the outer circumferential or belt highway
is the rim, and the inner belt around the central business district is the
hub; large cities also may have an intermediate belt. Local conditions
may distort the symmetry of the wheel pattern and even eliminate parts
of it, but in general the overall pattern is much the same for all cities . . . .
The type of highway-freeway, at-grade expressway, or major street—to
be used in the arterial highway pattern is determined by joint consider-
ation of the type of facility needed to carry the traffic load and that
physically and economically is feasible in that part of the city. The larger
the urban area, the greater is the necessity for high-type facilities. In a
typical large city (500,000 - 1,000,000) the framework of the arterial
system consists of several expressway or freeway radial routes and two
or more belts. Major streets complete the system.”
